  • Troubleshooting - Common configuration issues
  • Quick Start - Basic configuration examples

docs.title: Guide: Matrix Testing with Stir
docs.text: The soup stir command is a powerful tool for running parallel integration tests. It includes matrix testing capabilities to validate your Terraform configurations against multiple versions of Terraform or OpenTofu.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Matrix testing is an optional feature that requires the wrknv package:

# Install wrknv from PyPI (when available)
pip install wrknv

# Or install from local source (development)
pip install -e /path/to/wrknv

Note: All other TofuSoup features work without wrknv. Only the soup stir --matrix flag requires this dependency. The wrknv package is not yet published to PyPI and must be installed separately.

docs.title: What is Matrix Testing?
docs.text: Matrix testing executes your test suite across multiple tool versions to ensure broad compatibility. This is essential for: - Validating provider compatibility across Terraform versions - Testing migration paths between OpenTofu and Terraform - Ensuring backward compatibility - Catching version-specific bugs

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Run tests across all configured tool versions:

# Run tests with matrix testing
soup stir tests/stir_cases --matrix

# Save detailed results
soup stir tests/stir_cases --matrix --matrix-output results.json

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Configure matrix testing in your soup.toml file:

[workenv.matrix]
parallel_jobs = 4              # Number of parallel test jobs
timeout_minutes = 30           # Timeout per test run

[workenv.matrix.versions]
terraform = ["1.5.7", "1.6.0", "1.6.1"]
tofu = ["1.6.2", "1.7.0", "1.8.0"]

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
• parallel_jobs: Number of tool versions to test concurrently (default: 4)
  • timeout_minutes: Maximum time for each test run (default: 30)
  • versions: Map of tool names to version lists

docs.title: How Matrix Testing Works
docs.text:
When you run soup stir --matrix, the following happens:

  1. Load Configuration: Reads matrix versions from soup.toml or wrkenv.toml
  2. Tool Management: Automatically downloads and manages required tool versions
  3. Parallel Execution: Runs tests across versions concurrently (respects parallel_jobs setting)
  4. Result Collection: Aggregates results from all version runs
  5. Report Generation: Creates detailed report showing compatibility across versions

The stir framework handles all version management automatically - you don't need to manually switch versions or manage tool installations.

docs.title: Test Directory Structure
docs.text:
Organize your test cases in subdirectories:

tests/stir_cases/
├── basic/
│   ├── main.tf
│   └── variables.tf
├── complex_resources/
│   ├── main.tf
│   └── outputs.tf
└── state_operations/
    ├── main.tf
    └── backend.tf

Each subdirectory represents a test case. Stir will: - Run terraform init in each directory - Execute terraform plan and terraform apply - Verify successful execution - Clean up resources

docs.title: Single Version (No Matrix)
docs.text:
Run tests with the default Terraform/OpenTofu version:

soup stir tests/stir_cases

docs.title: Matrix Testing
docs.text:
Run tests across all configured versions:

soup stir tests/stir_cases --matrix

docs.title: With Results Output
docs.text:
Save detailed results for analysis:

soup stir tests/stir_cases --matrix --matrix-output results.json

The output includes: - Pass/fail status for each version - Execution times - Error messages - Version-specific differences

docs.title: Testing OpenTofu Compatibility
docs.text:
[workenv.matrix.versions]
terraform = ["1.5.7"]      # Last pre-fork version
tofu = ["1.6.0", "1.6.2"]  # OpenTofu versions

docs.title: Comprehensive Version Coverage
docs.text:
[workenv.matrix]
parallel_jobs = 8           # More parallelism
timeout_minutes = 45        # Longer timeout

[workenv.matrix.versions]
terraform = [
    "1.5.7",   # Stable
    "1.6.0",   # Latest 1.6
    "1.6.1",   # Patch release
]
tofu = [
    "1.6.2",   # Current stable
    "1.7.0",   # Latest release
    "1.8.0",   # Beta/RC testing
]

docs.title: CI/CD Configuration
docs.text:
[workenv.matrix]
parallel_jobs = 4
timeout_minutes = 20        # Stricter timeout for CI

[workenv.matrix.versions]
terraform = ["1.5.7", "1.6.0"]
tofu = ["1.6.2"]

docs.title: Success Output
docs.text:
✓ terraform 1.5.7: All tests passed (45.2s)
✓ terraform 1.6.0: All tests passed (43.8s)
✓ tofu 1.6.2: All tests passed (44.1s)

Matrix Test Summary: 3/3 passed

docs.title: Failure Output
docs.text:
✓ terraform 1.5.7: All tests passed (45.2s)
✗ terraform 1.6.0: 1/3 tests failed (38.1s)
  - complex_resources: Provider compatibility issue
✓ tofu 1.6.2: All tests passed (44.1s)

Matrix Test Summary: 2/3 passed (1 failed)

docs.title: Tests Timeout
docs.text:
If tests consistently timeout:

[workenv.matrix]
timeout_minutes = 60  # Increase timeout

docs.title: Tool Download Failures
docs.text: The framework automatically downloads tool versions. If downloads fail: - Check internet connectivity - Verify version numbers are correct - Check disk space

docs.title: Version Not Found
docs.text:
If a specified version doesn't exist: 

Error: Version 'terraform 1.9.9' not found

Solution: Verify version exists at: - Terraform: https://releases.hashicorp.com/terraform/ - OpenTofu: https://github.com/opentofu/opentofu/releases

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start Small: Begin with 2-3 versions, expand as needed
  2. Include Edge Cases: Test both oldest and newest supported versions
  3. Regular Updates: Update matrix versions quarterly
  4. CI Integration: Run matrix tests in pull requests
  5. Monitor Execution Time: Adjust parallel_jobs based on available resources

docs.title: Advanced: Workenv Integration
docs.text:
TofuSoup's matrix testing integrates with the wrkenv tool management system. You can also configure versions in wrkenv.toml:

# wrkenv.toml (alternative to soup.toml)
terraform_flavor = "opentofu"

[tools]
terraform = "1.5.7"
tofu = "1.6.2"

[matrix.versions]
terraform = ["1.5.7", "1.6.0"]
tofu = ["1.6.2", "1.7.0"]

Note: Settings in soup.toml take precedence over wrkenv.toml.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Configuration Reference - Complete soup.toml documentation
  • Quick Start - Basic stir usage
  • Troubleshooting - Common issues and solutions

docs.title: Guide: Terraform State Inspection
docs.text: TofuSoup provides tools for inspecting Terraform state files, including support for decrypting private state data stored by Pyvider providers.

docs.title: What is Private State?
docs.text:
Terraform providers can store sensitive data in "private state" - encrypted attributes that aren't visible in regular Terraform state inspection tools. Pyvider providers use this feature to securely store credentials, tokens, and other sensitive data.

TofuSoup's soup state commands can decrypt and display this private state data when you have the appropriate decryption key.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
To decrypt private state, you need:

  1. Shared Secret: Set via environment variable 

    export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="your-secret-key"

  2. State File: A Terraform state file (typically terraform.tfstate)

docs.title: Show State Overview
docs.text:
Display an overview of all resources in a state file:

soup state show

By default, this reads terraform.tfstate in the current directory.

You can specify a different state file:

soup state show path/to/terraform.tfstate

docs.title: Show Only Resources with Private State
docs.text:
Filter to only resources that contain private state:

soup state show --private-only

docs.title: Show Specific Resource
docs.text:
Display detailed information about a specific resource:

soup state show --resource pyvider_timed_token.example

Format: <resource_type>.<resource_name>

docs.title: Include Encrypted Data
docs.text:
Show both decrypted and encrypted versions of private state:

soup state show --show-encrypted

This is useful for debugging encryption issues or verifying that decryption is working correctly.

docs.title: Decrypting Individual Values
docs.text:
Decrypt a single base64-encoded private state string:

soup state decrypt "PaDuMfrlCnnhZsKb..."

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text:
# JSON output (default)
soup state decrypt "PaDuMfrlCnnhZsKb..." --format json

# Raw output
soup state decrypt "PaDuMfrlCnnhZsKb..." --format raw

docs.title: Validating State File
docs.text:
Check that all private state in a state file can be successfully decrypted:

soup state validate
soup state validate path/to/terraform.tfstate

This command: - Scans all resources in the state file - Attempts to decrypt any private state data - Reports any decryption failures - Returns exit code 0 if all validations pass

docs.title: 1. Set Your Shared Secret
docs.text: export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="$(cat .secrets/private-state-key)"

docs.title: 2. View State Overview
docs.text:
soup state show

Output: 

📋 Terraform State: terraform.tfstate

Resources with Private State:
├── pyvider_timed_token.api_token
├── pyvider_credential.database
└── pyvider_secret.api_key

Total Resources: 15
Resources with Private State: 3

docs.title: 3. Inspect Specific Resource
docs.text:
soup state show --resource pyvider_timed_token.api_token

Output: 

🔍 Resource: pyvider_timed_token.api_token

Public Attributes:
├── id: "token-12345"
├── expiry: "2025-12-31T23:59:59Z"
└── created_at: "2025-01-01T00:00:00Z"

Private State (Decrypted):
├── token_value: "sk-proj-abc123..."
├── refresh_token: "rt-xyz789..."
└── encryption_metadata:
    ├── algorithm: "AES-256-GCM"
    └── key_id: "key-001"

docs.title: 4. Validate All Private State
docs.text:
soup state validate

Output: 

✅ All private state validated successfully
- pyvider_timed_token.api_token: OK
- pyvider_credential.database: OK
- pyvider_secret.api_key: OK

docs.title: Debugging Provider Issues
docs.text:
When troubleshooting provider problems, inspect the state to verify what's stored:

# See all private state
soup state show --private-only

# Check specific resource
soup state show --resource pyvider_credential.db_creds

docs.title: Rotating Encryption Keys
docs.text:
When rotating private state encryption keys:

# Validate with old key
export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="old-key"
soup state validate

# After rotation, validate with new key
export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="new-key"
soup state validate

docs.title: CI/CD State Verification
docs.text:
In CI/CD pipelines, verify state file integrity:

#!/bin/bash
set -e

# Load secret from CI secrets
export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="$CI_PRIVATE_STATE_KEY"

# Validate state
soup state validate terraform.tfstate

# Show summary
soup state show --private-only

docs.title: Manual Decryption
docs.text:
Decrypt individual values from logs or debug output:

# From provider logs
soup state decrypt "eyJhbGciOiJkaXIi..."

# Save to file
soup state decrypt "eyJhbGciOiJkaXIi..." --format raw > decrypted.txt

docs.title: Missing Shared Secret
docs.text:
Error: PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET not set

Solution: 

export PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET="your-key"

docs.title: Decryption Failure
docs.text:
Error: Failed to decrypt private state

Possible causes: 1. Wrong shared secret 2. Corrupted encrypted data 3. Incompatible encryption version

Debug steps: 

# Try showing encrypted data
soup state show --show-encrypted

# Validate state file
soup state validate

# Check provider logs
terraform plan

docs.title: State File Not Found
docs.text:
Error: State file not found: terraform.tfstate

Solution: 

# Specify full path
soup state show /path/to/terraform.tfstate

# Or change directory
cd /path/to/terraform/project
soup state show

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
1. Protect Your Shared Secret: Never commit PYVIDER_PRIVATE_STATE_SHARED_SECRET to version control

  2. Secure State Files: Terraform state files contain sensitive data, even without private state

  3. Use Remote State: Consider using remote state backends with encryption at rest

  4. Rotate Keys Regularly: Periodically rotate your private state encryption keys

  5. Limit Access: Restrict who can decrypt private state in production environments

docs.title: Integration with Terraform
docs.text:
TofuSoup's state inspection works alongside standard Terraform commands:

# Standard Terraform state inspection
terraform state list
terraform state show pyvider_timed_token.example

# TofuSoup private state inspection
soup state show --resource pyvider_timed_token.example

Use terraform state for public attributes and soup state for private state data.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Pyvider Documentation - Provider framework with private state support
  • Terraform State - Official Terraform state documentation
  • Troubleshooting - Common issues and solutions

docs.title: Working with Wire Protocol
docs.text: This guide covers TofuSoup's wire protocol utilities for encoding and decoding Terraform's binary protocol format.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Terraform wire protocol is the binary format used for communication between Terraform and providers. It uses MessagePack encoding with Base64 wrapping for transmission.

TofuSoup provides tools to: - Encode JSON values to wire format - Decode wire format back to JSON - Validate cross-language compatibility - Debug protocol issues

docs.title: Wire Protocol Format
docs.text: The wire format consists of: 1. MessagePack encoding: Binary serialization of CTY values 2. Base64 encoding: ASCII-safe transport encoding 3. Type information: Preserved through encoding/decoding

docs.title: Encoding to Wire Format
docs.text:
Convert JSON to wire format:

# Create a JSON value
echo '{"value": "hello", "type": "string"}' > input.json

# Encode to wire format
soup wire encode input.json output.tfw.b64

# View the encoded output
cat output.tfw.b64

docs.title: Decoding from Wire Format
docs.text:
Convert wire format back to JSON:

# Decode wire format
soup wire decode output.tfw.b64 decoded.json

# Verify it matches the original
diff input.json decoded.json

docs.title: Objects
docs.text:
cat > object.json <<EOF
{
  "value": {
    "name": "example",
    "count": 42,
    "enabled": true
  },
  "type": {
    "object": {
      "name": "string",
      "count": "number",
      "enabled": "bool"
    }
  }
}
EOF

soup wire encode object.json object.tfw.b64
soup wire decode object.tfw.b64 object_decoded.json

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
cat > list.json <<EOF
{
  "value": ["one", "two", "three"],
  "type": {"list": "string"}
}
EOF

soup wire encode list.json list.tfw.b64

docs.title: Maps
docs.text:
cat > map.json <<EOF
{
  "value": {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"},
  "type": {"map": "string"}
}
EOF

soup wire encode map.json map.tfw.b64

docs.title: Dynamic Types
docs.text:
cat > dynamic.json <<EOF
{
  "value": "any value",
  "type": "dynamic"
}
EOF

soup wire encode dynamic.json dynamic.tfw.b64

docs.title: Cross-Language Compatibility Testing
docs.text:
Verify that Python and Go implementations produce identical wire format:

# Run wire protocol conformance tests
soup test wire

# Run with verbose output
soup test wire -v

The tests validate: - ✅ Encoding produces identical binary output - ✅ Decoding recovers exact original values - ✅ Type information is preserved - ✅ Edge cases are handled correctly

docs.title: View Wire Format as Hex
docs.text:
# Encode to wire format
soup wire encode input.json output.tfw.b64

# Decode Base64 and view as hex
base64 -d output.tfw.b64 | xxd

docs.title: Compare Python vs Go Encoding
docs.text:
# Using Python implementation
soup wire encode --implementation python input.json python.tfw.b64

# Using Go harness
./bin/soup-go wire encode input.json go.tfw.b64

# Compare binary output
diff python.tfw.b64 go.tfw.b64

docs.title: Binary Mismatch Errors
docs.text:
If you see "Binary mismatch" in conformance tests:

  1. Check input format is valid
  2. Verify type specifications are correct
  3. Review MessagePack encoding differences
  4. Check for float precision issues

docs.title: Type Preservation
docs.text:
Ensure type information is included:

{
  "value": 42,
  "type": "number"  // Required!
}

Without type info, encoding may fail or produce incorrect results.

docs.title: Null vs Unknown
docs.text:
CTY distinguishes between: - Null: Explicitly null value - Unknown: Value not yet known (during plan)

// Null value
{"value": null, "type": "string"}

// Unknown value
{"value": null, "type": "string", "unknown": true}

docs.title: Integration with Pyvider
docs.text:
When building Terraform providers with Pyvider:

from pyvider.wire import encode_value, decode_value
from pyvider.cty import Value, Type

# Create a CTY value
value = Value.from_json({"name": "example"})
type_spec = Type.object({"name": Type.string()})

# Encode to wire format
wire_bytes = encode_value(value, type_spec)

# Decode from wire format
decoded_value = decode_value(wire_bytes, type_spec)

docs.title: Custom MessagePack Options
docs.text:
For debugging, you can work directly with MessagePack:

import msgpack
from pathlib import Path

# Read wire format
with open("output.tfw.b64", "r") as f:
    import base64
    wire_bytes = base64.b64decode(f.read())

# Unpack MessagePack
data = msgpack.unpackb(wire_bytes, raw=False)
print(data)

docs.title: Performance Testing
docs.text:
Benchmark encoding/decoding performance:

# Time encoding operation
time for i in {1..1000}; do
  soup wire encode input.json output.tfw.b64
done

# Compare Python vs Go performance
pytest conformance/wire/test_performance.py

  • Debug any binary mismatch issues

docs.title: Guide: Running Conformance Tests
docs.text: The soup test command is the unified entry point for running all Pytest-based conformance test suites. These tests (souptest_*.py) are specifically for verifying cross-language compatibility against the Go harnesses.

docs.title: Running All Suites
docs.text:
To execute every defined test suite, use the all subcommand. This is the most common command for a full regression check.

soup test all

docs.title: Running a Specific Suite
docs.text:
You can run a specific suite by name. This is useful for focusing on a particular area of compatibility during development.

# Run only the CTY compatibility tests
soup test cty

# Run only the RPC compatibility tests
soup test rpc

Available suites include cty, rpc, wire, hcl, and more.

docs.title: Passing Arguments to Pytest
docs.text:
Any arguments provided after the suite name are passed directly to pytest. This allows you to use any standard pytest flag, such as running tests by keyword (-k) or by marker (-m).

# Run only tests with "some_test_name" in their name within the 'cty' suite
soup test cty -k "some_test_name"

# Run all 'rpc' tests except those marked as 'slow'
soup test rpc -m "not slow"

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Test behavior, such as environment variables, default pytest arguments, and tests to skip, can be configured globally or per-suite in your soup.toml file.

Example soup.toml: ```toml [test_suite_defaults] extra_pytest_args = ["-m", "not slow"]

[test_suite.rpc]

docs.title: Set an environment variable only for the RPC test suite
docs.text: env_vars = { SKIP_RUBY_RPC_TESTS = "1" }```

docs.title: Guide: Managing Language-Specific CLIs
docs.text: The soup harness command is used to manage the lifecycle of language-specific implementations of the TofuSoup CLI, such as soup-go. These binaries provide feature parity with the main Python CLI and serve as the canonical reference for conformance tests.

docs.title: Listing CLIs
docs.text:
To see a list of available language-specific CLIs and their current build status, use the list command.

soup harness list
This will display a table showing each CLI, its expected binary path, and whether it is currently built.

docs.title: Building CLIs
docs.text:
The build command compiles the source code for the language-specific CLIs and places the executables in a standardized location (tofusoup/src/tofusoup/harness/go/bin/).

# Build all available CLIs
soup harness build --all

# Build a specific CLI, for example soup-go
soup harness build soup-go

# Force a rebuild even if the binary already exists
soup harness build soup-go --force-rebuild

Build behavior, such as Go build flags and environment variables, can be customized in soup.toml.

docs.title: Verifying CLIs
docs.text:
After building, you can run a basic verification check to ensure the CLI is functional.

soup harness verify-cli soup-go

docs.title: Cleaning CLIs
docs.text:
The clean command removes the compiled binary artifacts for one or more CLIs.

# Clean a specific CLI
soup harness clean soup-go

# Clean all built CLIs
soup harness clean --all

docs.title: RPC Cross-Language Compatibility Matrix
docs.text: This document details the compatibility matrix for cross-language RPC connections in tofusoup, including client-server language pairs and cryptographic curve support.

docs.title: Language Pair Compatibility
docs.text: Client → Server Status Notes Python → Python ✅ Supported Full support with all features Go → Python ✅ Supported Recommended for cross-language scenarios Go → Go ✅ Supported Full support with all features Python → Go ❌ Not Supported Known bug in pyvider-rpcplugin

docs.title: Python → Go Connection Failure
docs.text:
Problem: Python clients cannot connect to Go servers due to a TLS handshake incompatibility in pyvider-rpcplugin.

Symptoms: - Connection timeout after 10-30 seconds - TLS handshake failure errors - Server process starts but client cannot establish channel

Workarounds: 1. Use Go client → Python server (recommended for cross-language scenarios) 2. Use Python client → Python server (pure Python) 3. Use Go client → Go server (pure Go)

Related Issues: - pyvider-rpcplugin: Incompatibility with go-plugin server TLS handshake - Expected to be resolved in future pyvider releases

docs.title: Python Runtime (grpcio)
docs.text: Curve Status Notes secp256r1 (P-256) ✅ Supported Recommended, widely compatible secp384r1 (P-384) ✅ Supported Higher security margin secp521r1 (P-521) ❌ Not Supported grpcio limitation

docs.title: Go Runtime (crypto/tls)
docs.text: Curve Status Notes secp256r1 (P-256) ✅ Supported Recommended, widely compatible secp384r1 (P-384) ✅ Supported Higher security margin secp521r1 (P-521) ✅ Supported Highest security, Go only

docs.title: Curve Compatibility Notes
docs.text:
• Python servers: Only accept connections with secp256r1 or secp384r1
  • Go servers: Accept connections with any standard NIST curve
  • Cross-language: When connecting Go → Python, use secp256r1 or secp384r1
  • Auto mode: Set tls_curve="auto" to let the runtime choose (uses secp256r1)

docs.title: Supported TLS Modes
docs.text: Mode Description Compatibility disabled No encryption Both Python and Go auto Automatic mTLS with generated certs Both Python and Go manual User-provided certificates Both Python and Go

docs.title: TLS Mode Requirements
docs.text:
Auto Mode: - Server and client must both use auto mode - Specify tls_key_type (default: "ec") - Specify tls_curve for EC keys (default: "secp256r1") - Certificates generated automatically

Manual Mode: - Provide cert_file and key_file parameters - Certificates must be compatible (matching key types and curves) - Both client and server need matching CA certificates

docs.title: Automated Test Coverage
docs.text:
The test suite validates all supported combinations:

# Run all compatibility tests
pytest tests/integration/

# Run specific test suites
pytest tests/integration/test_cross_language_matrix.py    # Language pairs
pytest tests/integration/test_curve_support.py            # Curve validation
pytest tests/integration/test_error_scenarios.py          # Error handling

docs.title: Test Matrix
docs.text:
The following combinations are tested automatically:

Test Scenario Client Server Curve Expected Result Python basic Python Python secp256r1 ✅ Pass Python P-384 Python Python secp384r1 ✅ Pass Go → Python Go Python auto ✅ Pass Go → Go Go Go secp384r1 ✅ Pass Python P-521 Python Python secp521r1 ❌ Expected Fail Python → Go Python Go any ⏭️ Skipped (known bug)

docs.title: CLI Validation
docs.text:
Use the validation command to check compatibility before connecting:

# Check if a connection will work
soup rpc validate-connection --client python --server harnesses/bin/soup-go

# Output:
# ⚠️  Python → Go connections not supported
# ✓  Supported alternatives:
#    - Go → Python (recommended)
#    - Python → Python
#    - Go → Go

docs.title: For Production Use
docs.text:
1. Use Go → Python for cross-language scenarios (most reliable)
  2. Use secp256r1 or secp384r1 for Python servers
  3. Use auto TLS mode unless you have specific cert requirements
  4. Test your configuration with soup rpc validate-connection before deployment

docs.title: For Development
docs.text:
1. Use Python → Python for quick iteration on Python code
  2. Use Go → Go for quick iteration on Go code
  3. Avoid Python → Go until the bug is fixed
  4. Run integration tests to verify your setup: pytest tests/integration/

docs.title: Error Messages
docs.text: When encountering compatibility issues, the client provides helpful error messages:

docs.title: Python → Go Timeout
docs.text:
Connection timeout after 15.234s - Python client → Go server is not supported.

This is a known issue in pyvider-rpcplugin.

Supported alternatives:
  ✓ Go client → Python server (use soup-go binary as client)
  ✓ Python client → Python server
  ✓ Go client → Go server

Server path: harnesses/bin/soup-go

docs.title: Unsupported Curve
docs.text:
Curve 'secp521r1' is not supported by Python's grpcio library.
Supported curves for Python: secp256r1, secp384r1

Original error: TimeoutError: Connection timeout

docs.title: Future Improvements
docs.text:
Planned enhancements to the compatibility matrix:

  1. Fix Python → Go connection (pyvider-rpcplugin update needed)
  2. Add Rust client/server support (future runtime)
  3. Add secp521r1 support for Python (requires grpcio update or alternative)
  4. Enhanced curve negotiation (automatic downgrade for compatibility)

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• RPC Matrix Specification
  • Running Conformance Tests
  • Cross-Language Compatibility
  • pyvider-rpcplugin Documentation

Last Updated: 2025-10-11

docs.title: TofuSoup Configuration (soup.toml)
docs.text: TofuSoup uses a TOML file named soup.toml for configuration. This file allows users to customize default behaviors for various commands, harness settings, and test execution parameters.

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
TofuSoup searches for soup.toml in the following order: 1. Path specified by the global --config-file <path> CLI option. 2. ./soup.toml (in the current working directory). 3. <project_root>/soup/soup.toml (recommended default location).

If no configuration file is found, TofuSoup operates with built-in defaults.

docs.title: Precedence
docs.text: For settings that can be defined in multiple places, the following order of precedence applies (highest to lowest): 1. Command-line arguments. 2. Environment variables (e.g., TOFUSOUP_LOG_LEVEL). 3. Settings in soup.toml. 4. Hardcoded application defaults.

docs.title: [global_settings]
docs.text:
Settings that apply across the TofuSoup application.

  • default_python_log_level (String): Sets the default logging level for TofuSoup's own Python-based logging. Valid values: "TRACE", "DEBUG", "INFO", "WARNING", "ERROR", "CRITICAL".
  • default_harness_log_level (String): A general default log level for external Go harnesses. Valid values for Go harnesses: "TRACE", "DEBUG", "INFO", "WARN", "ERROR".

docs.title: [harness_defaults.<language>]
docs.text:
Provides default settings for all harnesses of a specific language (e.g., [harness_defaults.go]).

  • build_flags (Array of Strings): Default flags passed to go build.
  • common_env_vars (Table): Environment variables to set for all Go harness operations.
  • default_log_level (String): Default log level specifically for Go harnesses.
  • timeout_seconds (Integer): Default timeout for running Go harness commands.

docs.title: [harness.<language>."<component_id>"]
docs.text:
Specific settings for an individual harness, overriding language defaults. Example: [harness.go.cty].

  • build_flags, custom_env_vars, log_level, timeout_seconds.

docs.title: [command_options."<command_group>.<command_name>"]
docs.text:
Provides default values for specific CLI command options.

Example: 

[command_options."hcl.convert"]
default_output_format = "json"

docs.title: [test_suite_defaults]
docs.text:
Default settings applicable to all test suites run via soup test.

  • env_vars (Table): Environment variables to set for all test runs.
  • extra_pytest_args (Array of Strings): Additional arguments always passed to pytest.
  • skip_tests (Array of Strings): Test items to skip.

docs.title: [test_suite.<suite_name>]
docs.text:
Specific settings for a named test suite (e.g., [test_suite.rpc]), overriding defaults.

  • env_vars, extra_pytest_args, skip_tests.

docs.title: [workenv]
docs.text:
Configuration for tool management, powered by wrkenv. When configured in soup.toml, these settings are injected into wrkenv, making wrkenv.toml optional.

  • terraform_flavor (String): Default terraform flavor - "terraform" or "opentofu"
  • tools (Table): Tool versions to use (e.g., terraform = "1.5.7")
  • settings (Table): Various settings like verify_checksums and cache_downloads

docs.title: [workenv.matrix]
docs.text:
Configuration for matrix testing with soup stir --matrix.

  • versions (Table): Additional versions to test for each tool
  • parallel_jobs (Integer): Number of parallel test jobs (default: 4)
  • timeout_minutes (Integer): Timeout for each test run (default: 30)

Example: 

[workenv]
terraform_flavor = "opentofu"

[workenv.tools]
terraform = "1.8.5"
tofu = "1.10.5"

[workenv.settings]
verify_checksums = true
cache_downloads = true

[workenv.matrix]
parallel_jobs = 8
timeout_minutes = 45

[workenv.matrix.versions]
terraform = ["1.5.7", "1.6.0", "1.6.1"]
tofu = ["1.6.2", "1.7.0", "1.8.0"]

Note: You can alternatively configure wrkenv using a wrkenv.toml file. Settings in soup.toml take precedence over wrkenv.toml.

docs.title: TofuSoup API Reference
docs.text: This page provides auto-generated API documentation for the tofusoup Python package.

docs.title: Using TofuSoup as a Library
docs.text:
While TofuSoup is primarily a CLI tool, you can also use its components programmatically:

# CTY operations
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file, view_cty_file

# HCL operations
from tofusoup.hcl.logic import parse_hcl_file, convert_hcl_file

# Wire protocol operations
from tofusoup.wire.logic import encode_wire, decode_wire

# Configuration
from tofusoup.common.config import load_tofusoup_config

docs.title: CTY Operations
docs.text:
Convert CTY files between formats:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file

# Convert JSON to MessagePack
success = convert_cty_file(
    input_path=Path("data.json"),
    output_path=Path("data.msgpack"),
    input_format="json",
    output_format="msgpack"
)

if success:
    print("Conversion successful!")

View CTY structure:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.cty.logic import view_cty_file

# Display CTY structure as rich tree
view_cty_file(
    file_path=Path("data.json"),
    file_format="json"
)

docs.title: HCL Operations
docs.text:
Parse HCL files:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.hcl.logic import parse_hcl_file

# Parse HCL file and get CTY representation
cty_value = parse_hcl_file(Path("main.tf"))
print(f"Parsed HCL: {cty_value}")

Convert HCL to other formats:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.hcl.logic import convert_hcl_file

# Convert HCL to JSON
convert_hcl_file(
    input_path=Path("config.hcl"),
    output_path=Path("config.json"),
    output_format="json"
)

docs.title: Wire Protocol
docs.text:
Encode and decode wire protocol messages:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.wire.logic import encode_wire, decode_wire

# Encode JSON to wire format
encode_wire(
    input_json_path=Path("value.json"),
    output_tfw_b64_path=Path("value.tfw.b64")
)

# Decode wire format to JSON
decode_wire(
    input_tfw_b64_path=Path("value.tfw.b64"),
    output_json_path=Path("decoded.json")
)

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Load TofuSoup configuration:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.common.config import load_tofusoup_config

# Load from project root
config = load_tofusoup_config(
    project_root=Path.cwd(),
    explicit_config_file=None
)

# Access configuration
log_level = config.get("global_settings", {}).get("default_python_log_level", "INFO")
print(f"Log level: {log_level}")

docs.title: Validation Pipeline
docs.text:
Build a validation pipeline using TofuSoup components:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file
from tofusoup.wire.logic import encode_wire, decode_wire

def validate_cty_roundtrip(input_file: Path) -> bool:
    """Validate CTY data through full encode/decode cycle."""
    temp_msgpack = Path("temp.msgpack")
    temp_wire = Path("temp.tfw.b64")
    temp_decoded = Path("temp_decoded.json")

    try:
        # Convert to msgpack
        convert_cty_file(input_file, temp_msgpack, "json", "msgpack")

        # Encode to wire format
        encode_wire(input_file, temp_wire)

        # Decode back
        decode_wire(temp_wire, temp_decoded)

        return True
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Validation failed: {e}")
        return False
    finally:
        # Cleanup
        for f in [temp_msgpack, temp_wire, temp_decoded]:
            if f.exists():
                f.unlink()

docs.title: Custom Test Harness
docs.text:
Use TofuSoup components to build custom test harnesses:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.common.config import load_tofusoup_config
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file

class CustomTestHarness:
    def __init__(self, config_path: Path):
        self.config = load_tofusoup_config(config_path.parent)
        self.test_data_dir = config_path.parent / "test_data"

    def run_conversion_tests(self):
        """Run all CTY conversion tests."""
        test_files = self.test_data_dir.glob("*.json")

        for test_file in test_files:
            output_file = test_file.with_suffix(".msgpack")
            success = convert_cty_file(
                test_file,
                output_file,
                "json",
                "msgpack"
            )
            print(f"Test {test_file.name}: {'PASS' if success else 'FAIL'}")

# Usage
harness = CustomTestHarness(Path("soup.toml"))
harness.run_conversion_tests()

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
Process multiple files with TofuSoup:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.hcl.logic import convert_hcl_file

def batch_convert_hcl(source_dir: Path, output_dir: Path):
    """Convert all HCL files in a directory to JSON."""
    output_dir.mkdir(exist_ok=True)

    for hcl_file in source_dir.glob("**/*.hcl"):
        output_file = output_dir / hcl_file.relative_to(source_dir).with_suffix(".json")
        output_file.parent.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

        try:
            convert_hcl_file(hcl_file, output_file, "json")
            print(f"✓ Converted {hcl_file.name}")
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"✗ Failed {hcl_file.name}: {e}")

# Usage
batch_convert_hcl(Path("terraform_configs"), Path("converted_json"))

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
TofuSoup components raise exceptions for errors. Always wrap calls in try-except blocks:

from pathlib import Path
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file
from tofusoup.common.exceptions import TofuSoupError

try:
    convert_cty_file(
        Path("input.json"),
        Path("output.msgpack"),
        "json",
        "msgpack"
    )
except TofuSoupError as e:
    print(f"TofuSoup error: {e}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Unexpected error: {e}")

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
TofuSoup uses structured logging via provide.foundation:

from provide.foundation import logger

# TofuSoup functions log automatically
from tofusoup.cty.logic import convert_cty_file

# Configure logging if needed
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

# Now CTY operations will log debug information
convert_cty_file(...)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This document tracks the status of conformance tests after migrating from separate harnesses (go-cty, go-hcl, go-wire) to the unified soup-go implementation.

docs.title: Test Results Summary
docs.text: As of the latest run: - 31 passed ✅ - 11 failed ❌ - 24 skipped ⏭️ - 85 deselected

docs.title: 1. HCL Error Handling
docs.text:
Issue: soup-go returns exit code 0 even for parse errors, with errors in JSON output - Test expects: Exit code 1 for syntax errors - soup-go returns: Exit code 0 with {"success": false, "errors": [...]}

Affected tests: - test_hcl_cli_parse[parse_syntax_error-soup-go]

docs.title: 2. Wire Protocol Format Differences
docs.text:
Issue: The old go-wire harness used base64 encoding, soup-go uses raw binary/msgpack - Tests expect: Base64-encoded wire format - soup-go provides: Raw msgpack bytes

Affected tests: - test_wire_cli_encode_simple_string - test_wire_cli_decode_simple_string

docs.title: 3. Command Structure Changes
docs.text:
All commands now require the subcommand prefix: - Old: go-cty validate ... - New: soup-go cty validate-value ...

  • Old: go-hcl parse ...

  • New: soup-go hcl parse ...

  • Old: go-wire encode ...

  • New: soup-go wire encode ...

docs.title: No Backward Compatibility
docs.text: Per user request, backward compatibility aliases have been removed. All tests must use soup-go directly with the appropriate subcommands.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: CTY test suite environment variables are properly configured via conformance/cty/conftest.py which loads settings from soup.toml: - TOFUSOUP_TEST_DEFAULT_ENV - TOFUSOUP_CTY_SUITE_ENV

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
1. Exit Code Behavior: Consider whether soup-go should return non-zero exit codes for errors to match typical CLI behavior, or if tests should be updated to check JSON success field.

  2. Wire Format: Decide on standard encoding (raw bytes vs base64) for wire protocol operations.

  3. Test Updates: Continue updating remaining tests to match soup-go's actual behavior as the reference implementation.

docs.title: Cross-Language Compatibility Testing
docs.text: This document describes how to run and verify cross-language compatibility between the Python soup CLI and the Go soup-go harness, ensuring that data structures (CTY values, HCL, wire protocol) can be correctly exchanged between implementations.

docs.title: 1. Build the Go Harness
docs.text:
The soup-go binary must be built before running tests:

cd src/tofusoup/harness/go/soup-go
go build -o $TOFUSOUP_ROOT/bin/soup-go .

The binary will be placed in /Users/tim/code/gh/provide-io/tofusoup/bin/soup-go.

docs.title: 2. Python Environment
docs.text:
Ensure the Python environment is activated with all dependencies:

uv sync  # Sets up the workenv (not .venv)

docs.title: CTY Compatibility Tests
docs.text: The primary cross-language compatibility tests are in conformance/cty/souptest_cty_interop.py.

docs.title: Run all CTY compatibility tests:
docs.text: pytest conformance/cty/souptest_cty_interop.py -v

docs.title: Run specific test cases:
docs.text:
# Test a specific case (e.g., string handling)
pytest conformance/cty/souptest_cty_interop.py -k "string_simple" -v

# Test unknown value handling (will be skipped for JSON input)
pytest conformance/cty/souptest_cty_interop.py -k "unknown" -v

docs.title: Test Flow
docs.text:
The cross-language tests verify bidirectional compatibility:

  1. Python → Go → Python: Python creates fixtures, Go processes them, Python validates
  2. Go → Python → Go: Go creates fixtures, Python processes them, Go validates

docs.title: Test Cases
docs.text: The test suite covers: - Basic types: strings, numbers, booleans - Null values: Proper null handling across languages - Unknown values: MessagePack-only (JSON not supported by go-cty) - Collections: Lists, sets, maps - Complex types: Objects, tuples, nested structures - Dynamic types: Dynamic pseudo-type wrapping

docs.title: Unknown Values and JSON
docs.text:
go-cty (and Terraform) CANNOT handle unknown values in JSON format. This is a fundamental limitation:

  • ❌ JSON → Unknown → Go: Will fail with "value is not known"
  • ✅ MessagePack → Unknown → Go: Works correctly
  • ✅ Go → Unknown → MessagePack: Works correctly
  • ❌ Go → Unknown → JSON: Will fail with "value is not known"

Tests involving unknown values through JSON are automatically skipped.

docs.title: Test basic conversion:
docs.text:
# JSON to MessagePack
echo '"hello"' | soup-go cty convert - - \
  --input-format json \
  --output-format msgpack \
  --type '"string"' | xxd

# MessagePack roundtrip
echo '"test"' | soup-go cty convert - - \
  --input-format json \
  --output-format msgpack \
  --type '"string"' | \
soup-go cty convert - - \
  --input-format msgpack \
  --output-format json \
  --type '"string"'

docs.title: Test validation:
docs.text:
# Validate a value
soup-go cty validate-value '"hello"' --type '"string"'

# Should output: "Validation Succeeded"

docs.title: Create a test HCL file:
docs.text:
cat > /tmp/test.hcl << 'EOF'
resource "example" "test" {
  name = "hello"
  count = 42
}
EOF

docs.title: Parse with soup-go:
docs.text:
soup-go hcl parse /tmp/test.hcl | python3 -m json.tool

Expected output: 

{
    "body": {
        "blocks": [
            {
                "body": {
                    "count": 42,
                    "name": "hello"
                },
                "labels": ["example", "test"],
                "type": "resource"
            }
        ]
    },
    "success": true
}

docs.title: Validate HCL syntax:
docs.text: soup-go hcl validate /tmp/test.hcl

docs.title: Test encoding/decoding:
docs.text:
# JSON to MessagePack wire format
echo '{"key": "value"}' | soup-go wire encode - - \
  --input-format json \
  --output-format msgpack | xxd

# With CTY type awareness
echo '"hello"' | soup-go wire encode - - \
  --input-format json \
  --output-format msgpack \
  --type '"string"' | xxd

docs.title: 1. Check Binary Version
docs.text:
Ensure soup-go is up to date: 

soup-go --version
# Should show: 0.1.0 or later

docs.title: 2. Verbose Logging
docs.text:
Run soup-go with verbose logging: 

soup-go --log-level debug cty convert - - \
  --input-format json \
  --output-format msgpack \
  --type '"string"' <<< '"test"'

docs.title: 3. Check MessagePack Formats
docs.text:
Python and Go use slightly different MessagePack extension formats for unknown values: - Python: c70000 (fixext2) - Go: d40000 (fixext1)

Both formats are interoperable and correctly handled by both implementations.

docs.title: "value is not known" Error
docs.text: This occurs when trying to convert unknown values through JSON. This is expected behavior matching Terraform. Use MessagePack for unknown values.

docs.title: "unknown flag" Error
docs.text:
The soup-go binary is outdated. Rebuild it: 

cd src/tofusoup/harness/go/soup-go
go build -o $TOFUSOUP_ROOT/bin/soup-go .

docs.title: Continuous Integration
docs.text:
For CI/CD pipelines, ensure:

  1. Go is installed (version 1.21+)
  2. Build soup-go before running tests: 
    make -C src/tofusoup/harness/go/soup-go build
  3. Run the test suite: 
    pytest conformance/cty/souptest_cty_interop.py --tb=short

docs.title: Reference Implementation
docs.text: The Go implementation (soup-go) serves as the reference implementation that exactly matches Terraform's behavior. No workarounds or Python-specific accommodations should be made in the Go code. Instead, Python tests should adapt to Go/Terraform's limitations (e.g., skipping unknown value tests for JSON input).
